text: I know that Thanksgiving time in my
house when the time comes to carve that
Turkey nobody wants to do it whether you
have a chicken or a turkey this is the
easiest most foolproof method we know to
carve we're gonna start by taking the
legs off working with one side so you're
gonna want to just separate the breast
from the leg right where they meet
carving down through that skin at a
certain point when you get down in there
you are definitely gonna hit a bone and
this thigh joint once I feel any kind of
resistance down there I'm gonna stop put
the knife down and just pull that leg up
off the bird here this is where we have
the oyster that sort of mythical little
nubbin of meat that everybody talks it
out and this is another time that I am
I'm gonna use my knife just to get a
nice clean separation it's kind of hard
to see when it's cooked but right here
there's sort of this little membrane
here put your knife right through that
you won't feel any resistance right now
for the breasts there's this Center bone
called the keel bone that goes right
down the center there you want to just
kind of go right to the side of that in
theory you'd kind of want to not leave
any meat at all on the carcass but the
fact is you're gonna leave a little bit
behind and that's good stuff to just
kind of you know pick off using your
fingers or even use the carcass for a
little bit of stock or something like
that and when it comes to carving the
turkey it's just a bigger burlier
version of this with a turkey it's like
even more important to kind of get your
hands involved you have like that joint
that you've just separated now the wing
is attached to the top of the breast and
we're gonna carve all the way down the
length of the breast here kind of until
I feel a good bit of resistance and it's
at that point I'm gonna kind of use my
fingers to kind of pull the breast away
from the carcass when you're trying to
get around those rib bones starting from
the back end the sort of like cavity and
if you will kind of makes a little bit
of a difference there working away from
back to forward or at least like kind of
in one direction helps just kind of get
around those bones and then get that
breast out of its own way and a
maintaining pressure on the breast to
kind of separate it so I can get the tip
of the knife in down there and now here
once you get to this stage you've carved
around the wishbone off of the ribs here
again we're gonna have that little wing
joint and even honestly for me I've
broken down probably
chickens I still this is the spot that's
like my demon spot it's like you know
this is where you're kind of like more
likely than not at least for me to sort
of run into a little bit of resistance
that you kind of can't really feel your
way around there we go
sometimes if you just sort of pull
things open a little bit it kind of gets
you the rest of the way there at this
point I usually will carve the chicken
breast in half that way everybody can
kind of have like a little bit of each
kind of neat so if you want ten pieces
taking off the wing is the way to get
there and to do that the joint kind of
goes in a little bit further so this is
that top of the joint that we had to
separate from the carcass right here so
we're just carving around that joint
so by carving in and around that tip
pull it away kind of comes away pretty
nicely so here it is low stress
roast chicken carbon so easy that next
time you might even fall a tear to do it
yourself
[Music]
